Award.AwardTitle: The Verbal Morpho-semantics and Clausal Architecture of Tlingit

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will conduct detailed, theoretically-informed fieldwork upon the Tlingit language (Lingít, /lin.kít/), a highly endangered and understudied language indigenous to Alaska, British Columbia, and the Yukon. The project will focus upon aspects of the language related to the expression of time and possibility, as well as the nature of the language's rather flexible word order.

This project will yield results of significance to both professional linguists and community members striving to learn Tlingit as a second language. Both groups will directly benefit from the collection of new Tlingit language data, given the language's status as highly endangered. In addition, study of the specific linguistic phenomena identified in this project will make distinct, important contributions to diverse areas of linguistic theory. For example, the investigation of word-order and sentence structure in Tlingit is expected to establish for linguists the existence of 'covert A-scrambling', a grammatical process whose existence is predicted by theory, but which has thus far not been definitively documented. Furthermore, study of the grammatical means by which Tlingit expresses the concepts of time and possibility will inform specific debates surrounding the extent to which languages vary in the expression of these concepts, thus probing deep and long-standing questions relating to human nature and the structure of human cognition.

Beyond these technical results, this project will advance ongoing efforts to document, maintain and revitalize the growing number of endangered languages throughout the world, mitigating the inevitable and catastrophic language death that will occur by the end of this century. This project will uncover subtle grammatical generalizations of no small importance to the growing number of persons learning Tlingit as a second language. Moreover, the digital recordings and field reports made during this project will be added to the archives stored at the Sealaska Heritage Institute and the Alaska Native Language Archive, preserving for future Tlingit generations the voices and the words of their forebears.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nature of the Project

This project has supported field research on the Tlingit language, a highly endangered and understudied language indigenous to Alaska, British Columbia, and the Yukon. The purpose of the research has been twofold: (i) to document via recordings, field reports, and published journal articles certain key features of the language’s grammar, and (ii) to determine how those grammatical features inform our broader understanding of how human languages do and do not differ from one another.

            The language data on which this project is based were gathered through interviews with some of the last remaining speakers of the Tlingit language. In total, eight Tlingit elders participated in the project: Kaséix (Selena Everson), Kaxwaan Éesh (George Davis), Keihéenák’w (John Martin), Kóoshdaak’w Éesh (William Fawcett), K’altseen (Carolyn Martin), Kaachkoo.aakw (Helen Sarabia), Shak’sháani (Margaret Dutson), and Yax?dulá?t (Lillian Austin). Over 46 hours worth of recordings were made with these elders; with their generous permission, all the recordings are available to the public online at the Alaska Native Language Archive (https://www.uaf.edu/anla/).

During this study, six major features of the Tlingit language were documented and analyzed. Although somewhat oversimplified, it would be fair to describe those features in the following non-technical terms: (i) the way that the language expresses possibility and necessity (so-called ‘modal constructions’), (ii) the way that the language expresses that something has occurred in the past (so-called ‘past tense’), (iii) the way that the language expresses that something will occur in the future (so-called ‘future tense’), (iv) the degree to which sentences in the language are composed of smaller phrases, (v) the way that certain antonyms in the language are expressed through negation (such as ‘not good’ meaning ‘bad’), (vi) the way that the language expresses generalities (such as ‘boys love dogs’).

These particular six features were chosen because of their interest and importance both to linguistic theoreticians and to Tlingit language teachers working to maintain and revitalize use of the language. Regarding their interest to linguistic theoreticians, the facts concerning these six features of Tlingit impact several larger debates within linguistic theory, all of which ultimately concern how human languages are (or are not) able to differ from one another. Regarding their interest to teachers, these six features were not adequately covered in previous documentary work on the language, and so more knowledge of them would be critical for the creation of more advanced language curricula and for faithful transmission of the language to younger generations.

Results, Outcomes, Products

During the life of the project, eight students were hired as research assistants; four were PhD students, while four were undergraduates. One of them was a Tlingit man, and five were women, groups that are generally underrepresented in the sciences. The research carried out by these RAs has lead to two successfully defended doctoral dissertations, as well as a successfully defended doctoral qualifying paper.

In addition to the many recordings mentioned earlier, the research carried out under this project has yielded a large number of scholarly works, which detail the results obtained regarding the six topics summarized above. This scholarly output includes 4 journal articles, two of which have been published, one of which is under revision for publication, and one of which is currently under review. All the articles were authored by PI Seth Cable, and were submitted to top-line linguistics journals. Some of this research was also published in a chapter within an edited volume (also by PI Cable). A total of 14 juried conference presentations resulted from this project, 3 by PI Cable and 11 by the graduate RAs; all appeared at major international linguistics conferences. From these conference presentations, 4 proceedings papers were published. In addition, the research supported by this grant has been presented at 16 different invited talks or plenary lectures, eight by PI Cable and eight by the graduate students RAs.

            Nine different specialized survey instruments were designed during the course of the study, each of which is now publicly available from ‘Totem Fields Storyboards’ (http://totemfieldstoryboards.org/). The authorship of these instruments is shared by Cable and the undergraduate RAs. Though these materials were used to study the Tlingit language, they were designed to be general enough for use by linguists and community language activists all around the world.

            Finally, in every year of the grant, PI Cable composed non-technical research reports summarizing the data and results of that year’s field research. These reports were written partly for Tlingit language learners and teachers, and so the writing is relatively accessible and non-technical. The reports were distributed to various Tlingit language teachers and activists, and have been deposited with the Alaska Native Language Archive.
